body: Please push an empty commit to retrigger test
doesn't seem to be building

This seems to be because when you cloned the repository, you are using the latest commit of the repository. The latest release of mxnet is of an older commit. The latest release information is here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases. 
To use the source code from latest release as of today (0.10.0.post2), try 
```git checkout 0.10.0.post2``` 
The example should work now.
PR #7222 should fix this issue.  Please try it out.
thanks it work fine for me

Yeah. Some nvcc issues. I also have to test a bit more the Cuda stuff. So please don't merge until I claim that it is clean from my side. 
Any preference where to put the lapack_api/linalg headers instead of include/mxnet?
Closing as #7221 covers more cases.

Initially Bhavin and I thought the output "(mismatch 0.09999999999999432%)" was the largest difference, but looking at the code it seems to be a ratio of how many elements were mismatched. Instead of calling "assert_allclose()" we should maybe call "test_utils.assert_almost_equal()" for better debugging.

@reminisce and I did some experiments, but we couldn't get the test to fail. So that change would give us better data points during builds, if they fail, so we can pick a new atol/rtol.

Do you mean the messages? That's just you trying to load the saved model with a higher version of MXNet. If you mean the numbers, those are features of the input after passing the input through all but the last couple of layers of the network.
I agree that making the simple bind c-api consistent between front-end languages is more preferable.

Hi, @moskewcz , I have used slurm to run distributed mxnet job in v0.9.5, but in v 0.10.0, when I run distributed mxnet job with gpu resources, it meet some questions.

e.g. I run a job in 2 nodes, and I have 1 gpu on each node. when I use "srun" to launch 1 root ,2 server ,2 worker, and of course the 2 worker progress will use gpu resources. So ,the question is the root and server progresses have no gpu resources, it report a error.

Do you have any solutions of this. thx a lot

I read the examples and the tutorials, but I don't think the example [tree_lstm](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/gluon/tree_lstm/main.py#L160) really does mini-batch physically. The example calculates forward() and backward() for every instance, then it just update gradients to weight after a batch_size, but in the core engine, the real calculation with CPU/GPU is not parallelized by mini-batch. Do I understand it right?

I think so. That's why it's needed to call `FillComputeZerosEx` before `return` when the input is not initialized, which I forgot to do. I will submit another pr to fix this issue for this op. Thanks.
Thanks for your answers! I download the latest releases and replace the older one, and then I can run the example.

hi all --

i'm not actively working on this, but it's still on my backlog and i'm still interested in it. for now, we're currently mostly okay with single-node (multi-gpu) training, using slurm to manage a moderate number of nodes/users, so distributed mxnet training+slurm isn't critical yet. i did some initial experiments using launch.py (ssh mode) + measure.py, and wasn't able to get that to work correctly / reliably, so i figure i'm not ready to approach the slurm integration side of things yet (although perhaps actual training works better than measure.py?).

after wading though various issues with the pslite build process and code (i.e. it downloads and static links it's own libprotobuf, making the resulting mxnet build incompatible with an app that uses some other protobuf version), i concluded that (IMO) there were too many levels of complexity involved in the mxnet distributed flow: too many repos, too many processes (root + servers + workers; i'd prefer just root + workers, or maybe just workers (mpi-style)), too much dead/experimental/oddly-shared code (e.g. rabit), unused modes, hard to trace call stacks (on startup, how does each process determine what it's job is, and what control flow path does it follow?), and so on, so that also didn't make me super-eager to dive into it in too much depth just yet. i assume many (some?) people do use distributed mode, and that maybe that number will increase over time. i'm somewhat hoping perhaps more documentation/stability/simplicity might materialize if i wait ... or there's always tensorflow in the google cloud ;)
@herokang that's right. Batching on a dynamic graph is not straightforward, and will take some work on the backend.
@szha so does mxnet have a plan on how to batch dynamic computation graphs? Like TensorFlow Fold.

[monitor](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/b3b21e4e2006a54ea11573f95d439b6d5d8aa928/python/mxnet/monitor.py#L16) can be [installed](http://mxnet.io/api/python/module.html#mxnet.module.BaseModule.install_monitor) when training in symbolic API with modules, assuming you're asking about symbolic API. Also, you may consider adopting [Gluon](http://mxnet.io/api/python/gluon.html), which provides imperative mode and layer abstractions that are easier to work with.
Can you show the full example?

I have the same problem as you. I was trying to install mxnet-cu80 on supercomputer, when I met this problem. I also did
module load cuda/8.0

But I still can't make it.

I have gone thru docs. I have seen "monitor"  is often helpful to print out the weights and intermediate outputs to understand what's going on and accuracy.
But i would like to visualize the outputs in terms of images for every layers(each layers has 2D several feature maps). I would like to visualize 2D feature maps in terms of images for every layer. Is there is such alternative.
worked.

Hi, the idea is to create a custom MAE loss function (with cap) cf. #3368 [https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3368](url).

  label <- mx.symbol.Variable("label")
  
  data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
  fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, name="fc1", num_hidden=8)
  relu1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, name="relu1", act_type="relu")
  fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(relu1, name="fc2", num_hidden=4)
  relu2<-mx.symbol.Activation(fc2, name="relu2", act_type="relu")
  fc3<- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(relu2, name="fc3", num_hidden=1)

  lro2<-mx.symbol.MakeLoss(mx.symbol.min(mx.symbol.abs(mx.symbol.Reshape(fc3, shape = 0) - 
  label),1.0),name="lro2")

Error in mx.varg.symbol.min(list(...)) :
symbol.cc:302: RCheck failed: keys[i].length() != 0 Non Symbol parameters is only accepted via key=value style.

Or I was trying to create a constant variable on which to run the min in MakeLoss, but can we in R define a constant value behind a symbol yet?...

  lossfloor <- mx.symbol.Variable("lossfloor")  # To be set to 1.0, but how?...
  lro2<-mx.symbol.MakeLoss(mx.symbol.min({mx.symbol.abs(mx.symbol.Reshape(fc3, shape = 0) - label);lossfloor}),name="lro2")

Thanks.
see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1473

I don't know if that's necessary (maybe it is -- I don't know your code as
well as you do). I just was referring to the statement that it was sort of
a requirement that the sparse tensor not be initialized yet, and was
wondering if it was a problem of reshaping on-the-fly or, like you said,
values I the tensor might have garbage values in them and it's not
reconciled. Is there something about the algorithm that would not touch
every active value in the array and leave the garbage value in the result?
My naive expectation is that every stored value would be written to during
the algorithm execution. Just wondering for my own education here.

@mkolod @piiswrong 
I managed to run a quick test with Sockeye that uses SequenceReverse in its RNN bi-directional encoders on different versions of mxnet: 0.10.0, latest master, master@8144361, and master@a8804a1b7 . The latter two correspond to mxnet just before this PR was merged and right after.

The table shows wall time after 2k batches and 10k batches in seconds on a single Tesla K80 (AWS p2.xlarge)

MXNet version|wall-time @ batch 2k|wall-time @ 10k batches
-|-|-
0.10.0|1357.811677|7224.344484
before PR (`814436`)|1389.247020|7370.476751
after PR (`a8804a`) |1686.342626|8827.216907
latest|1667.805436|8783.761625

This is obviously not a detailed profile but its pretty clear that the revised SequenceReverse operator slows things down quite a bit. Any idea what's going on there?
@fhieber @piiswrong I'll look into it today and will let you know what I find.

I fully agree, having something like Keras-vis (https://raghakot.github.io/keras-vis/#getting-started) for mxnet would be super cool, but I don't think there is any code available for that, at least I haven't found any. But it definitely should be possible to implement something like guided backprop for mxnet.

@sergeykolychev sparse tensor PR is a huge one. I think it will take a while before the sparse branch get fully reviewed and merged to master. For now I'm fine with an cpi compatible with perl and mark the old one deprecated. After perl moved from MXExecutorSimpleBind to MXExecutorSimpleBindEx, we can remove MXExecutorSimpleBind.

Why use heap when stack is enough?
why?
Thanks

I initialized like this because variable length array declaration like ```DType[n_channels]``` are not technically allowed by C++ standard. I read that g++ does allow it as an extension (if we don't use the flag ```-pedantic```. I have verified that ```DType[n_channels]``` does work on g++4.8 and g++5 on Linux. I wasn't sure if we can rely on this flag not being used. 

The alternative to the above would be dynamically create array using new.

Should I just declare it as ```DTypes[n_channels]```. It does work with the default config flags and config.mk configs.

@rahul003 just keep the size as a constant 4 should be fine. It's constant space, and n_channels is either 1, 3 or 4. Saving at most 3*sizeof(DType) doesn't change much, and in the alternative, you can keep the array on stack.
Currently, no.

Space wise it should be fine yes, but the goal was to address compiler warnings like below.
What do you think the best way to do remove these warnings would be?

```
src/io/iter_image_recordio_2.cc:407:17: warning: 'RGBA[1]' may be used uninitialized in this function [-Wmaybe-uninitialized]
src/io/iter_image_recordio_2.cc:407:17: warning: 'RGBA[3]' may be used uninitialized in this function [-Wmaybe-uninitialized]
src/io/iter_image_recordio_2.cc:407:17: warning: 'RGBA[2]' may be used uninitialized in this function [-Wmaybe-uninitialized]
```
`DType RGBA[4] = {}` or use `std::fill_n` after declaration should handle the initialization.

@fhieber @piiswrong 

I tried to repro the slowdown and was unable to. I compared the top of tree to the TOT with the commit in questions (a8804a) unapplied, on the following machine:

- Core i7-5930K CPU @ 3.50GHz (6 cores)
- 32 GB RAM
- Tesla P100 (Pascal)

While I don't see a slowdown, the speed-up is very minor, after the various refactorings done in the process of the code review for this PR. Initially, it was a difference between 20% of the execution time (prior to PR version 1) to 0.5% of the execution time. Unfortunately, since padding cannot be inverted and requires branching, and due to some other changes since the first commit, the gain is now 2% at best.

The Sockeye parameters I used were as follows (on WMT15 DE-EN dataset):

```
python3 -m sockeye.train \
        --source data/train2.de \
        --target data/train2.en \
        --validation-source data/valid2.de \
        --validation-target data/valid2.en \
        --output models \
        --num-words 50000 \
        --rnn-num-layers 2 \
        --rnn-num-hidden 512 \
        --num-embed-source 512 \
        --num-embed-target 512 \
        --max-seq-len 50 \
        --batch-size 64 \
        --bucket-width 10 \
        --checkpoint-frequency 20000 \
        --max-num-checkpoint-not-improved 8 \
        --dropout 0.3 \
        --optimizer adam \
        --clip-gradient 1.0 \
        --learning-rate-scheduler-type plateau-reduce \
        --learning-rate-reduce-factor 0.5 \
        --learning-rate-reduce-num-not-improved 3 \
        --attention-type dot \
        --learning-rate-half-life 10 \
        --monitor-bleu 10000 \
        --seed 42 \
        --use-fused-rnn \
        --device-ids 1 \
        --max-updates 2000
```

| MxNet version        | 1k batches           | 2k batches  |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
|  TOT      | 225s | 420s |
| TOT with commit a8804a unapplied       | 221s     | 419s  |

So, I can still see a speed-up (on Pascal), but it's much smaller than in the original commit, due to a different design (single MxNet kernel launch (but not single CUDA launch), honoring padding non-reversal as discussed earlier in the ticket, etc.).

I wonder if there is a different way to improve perf more, e.g. via a raw kernel rather than the magic macros, or if the current implementation is the best it can be from a performance perspective while using things such as MSHADOW_XINLINE. Maybe I'm missing some magic step here that is happening behind the scenes, since it's not an actual CUDA kernel written the traditional way, so maybe I missed some opportunities for perf improvement via these wrappers. In any case, I can't repro the slowdown on my end.

announcements should be ordered according to time.

Hi @sergeykolychev sorry for the delay. The reason the CI wasn't picking it up is because the default action is for it to pick up the Jenkinsfile from the branch, and not from your PR. From the build log:
> Loading trusted files from base branch master at a242e9f4b77bf705ae679de05642fbe88f870a9f rather than b7af850ed4278adad710e39a6dda39059999843b
Obtained Jenkinsfile from a242e9f4b77bf705ae679de05642fbe88f870a9f

There's also no easy way to test the Jenkinsfile locally. It's a [pain point](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36309063/how-can-i-test-a-change-made-to-jenkinsfile-locally) Jenkinsfile developers are going through. One thing we might be able to do is merge your code into a different (new) branch in order to test your changes. If it looks good, we make a pull request from that branch to the master branch.

Yes, so libmxnet.so is linked to a different OpenCV shared object than the
OpenCV python module (cv2.so).  There also appears to be a similar conflict
with two numpy versions. Try to remove your personal version of OpenCV and
rebuild.  try to use the official distributions of OpenCV rather than
personally-built ones or ones acquired by other means if you get this sort
of problem (or be sure to remove the official versions to use your own
build, etc).

Is this problem solved?
You can pass in params when creating block or modify grad_req after block is created

Sure, but thats in my opinion just a workaround. In that case one needs to manually create all parameter arrays. The alternative way requires an extra block.collect_params() and then modifying the grad_req attribute of all parameter arrays, which doesn't feel nice/polished to me either. I think setting grad_req should directly be supported by the mxnet API when creating a Block.

There are too many attributes for each parameter and too many parameters. Adding one argument for each case is not sustainable.

conv.weight.xxx = yyy is a better solution

Arguably though the library should take care of this and one shouldn't rely on the user setting it for each parameter separately. In the end then the complexity will be on the userside and not in the library. But the role of the library is to hide the complexity.

Another workaround may be to specify a default `grad_req` in `ParameterDict`. Thereby one can leverage the existing code that handles the passing of the `self.params` object and neverthelss integrate `grad_req` nicely in the API.

you can do it with
params = ParameterDict('conv0')
params.get('weight', grad_req = 'null')
conv0 = nn.Conv2D(prefix='conv0', params=params)
we can also add a setattr method to parameterdict that sets the attributes for each parameter

The idea behind this PR is that as Blocks can be arbitrarily composed, and as each block abstracts away the inner complexity (e.g. of an RNN Cell or a whole Network) the user may not know which parameters are initialized by the Block, which names they have, etc. Also changing the inner workings of a block (e.g. adding more operators, introducing extra parameters) should at best not make any changes outside of the block necessary. Your workaround does not fulfil these criteria as far as I understand.

So there should be some way to specify the `grad_req` without destroying the abstraction that the introduction of Blocks allowed us to have.

Regarding setattr for parameterdict, it should work if we always want to change the attributes of all parameters. I am wondering if there is a case in which the user may want to create a Block, that internally uses (lets say) 2 Blocks but each of them has a different grad_req.

In that case, with the API introduced by this PR, the user may add 2 parameters to the init function of his block, and pass the respective one to the Blocks that he uses to compose his block.

On the other hand for setattr one could introduce a prefix filter, that sets only the attributes of parameters whose name starts with the given prefix, which would result in the same behaviour.
I reverted the grad_req parameter and added the setattr function. If you reopen the PR github will show the changes.
@thinxer @pluskid @darxriggs @ry @jamesliu

Hi, yes, indeed the module has to be used for launch.py (even though I could not apply the changes to it, since it is in the MXNet repo).

Concerning the GPUs, yes, that is a known problem (to me). Launcher simply launches the same command line on servers and workers, and (if I remember correctly) if you don't specify --gpus=none, it looks for gpus. But if you specify it, then you will have no GPU on workers too.

So, in my opinion, you could modify the launcher (like slurm.py) to include the --gpus=none only for servers, but I can not guarantee it will work.

It's best to keep it consistent with MXNet nomenclature in general, so if
it's "X" and "BaseX" for other classes, I think it's nice to have
BaseSparseNDArray

Nikhil

also add len

Your code works for me. Although the right way to do it is either
```
with autograd.record():
    output, hidden = encoder(mx.nd.ones((8, 8, 300)), encoder_begin_state)

    hidden_detached = [i for i in hidden]

    prediction, _ = decoder(mx.nd.ones((8, 8, 300)), hidden_detached)
    l = loss(prediction, expected_label)

l.backward()
```

or

```
with autograd.record():
    output, hidden = encoder(mx.nd.ones((8, 8, 300)), encoder_begin_state)

    hidden_detached = [i.detach() for i in hidden]
    for i in hidden_detached:
        i.attach_grad()

    prediction, _ = decoder(mx.nd.ones((8, 8, 300)), hidden_detached)
    l = loss(prediction, expected_label)

l.backward()
autograd.backward(hidden, [hidden_detached[0].grad, hidden_detached[1].grad])
```
